newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta ends firmer given mark weakness.
newsitem.headline: Peseta ends firmer given mark weakness.

text.p: The peseta ended stronger on Monday, capitalising on the mark's overall weakness.
"What's happening is that the mark, as the main exponent of the future euro, is inspiring less confidence and this is reflected in the dollar's exchange rates," a dealer said.

Despite the peseta's rise, dealers expect the Bank of Spain to keep the price of money unchanged at 5.25 percent at Tuesday's auction and said they had not seen it intervening to curb the peseta's rise.
"I think this has more to do with mark weakness which is giving the peseta strength and therefore, it isn't necessary to take any steps to brake the peseta," a delaer said.
Of the 12 financial groups polled by Reuters, none forecast a reduction in the key rate on Tuesday.
At 1520 GMT, the mark was trading at 84.21/22, after an early 84.28/31 and late Friday's 84.32/35.
